Module jtrim.executor
Package org.jtrim2.executor

Class ThreadPoolBuilder

java.lang.Object
org.jtrim2.executor.ThreadPoolBuilder
public final class ThreadPoolBuilder extends Object
Defines a convenient build to create an executor relying on pooled threads. This builder allows to select the most efficient implementation for the set configuration. Therefore, it is recommended to use this builder over directly creating ThreadPoolTaskExecutor or SingleThreadedExecutor. In fact, this builder might select an implementation more efficient than what is otherwise publicly available.

If you want to create the executor in a single expression, then consider using the create factory method.

Thread safety

Instances of this class cannot be accessed from multiple threads concurrently. Concurrent access to instances of this class must be externally synchronized.

Synchronization transparency

Methods of this class are synchronization transparent.
See Also:
  • create(String, Consumer)

  • Constructor Details

    • ThreadPoolBuilder

      public ThreadPoolBuilder(String poolName)
      Creates and initializes the build with the given pool name, and
      • maxThreadCount = 1
      • maxQueueSize = Integer.MAX_VALUE
      • idleTimeout = 5 seconds
      • manualShutdownRequired = true
      • threadFactory = a factory creating non-daemon threads.
      Parameters:
      poolName - the name of the thread pool to be created. Unless you overwrite the thread factory with a custom implementation, this string will be part of the name of the threads of the thread pool. This argument cannot be null.

  • Method Details

    • create

      public static MonitorableTaskExecutorService create(String poolName, Consumer<? super ThreadPoolBuilder> config)
      Creates a thread pool executor using a ThreadPoolBuilder. This method is useful to create the thread pool in a single expression.

      This method call is effectively equivalent to 

      
 ThreadPoolBuilder builder = new ThreadPoolBuilder(poolName);
 config.accept(builder);
 return builder.build();
      Parameters:
      poolName - the name of the thread pool to be created. Unless you overwrite the thread factory with a custom implementation, this string will be part of the name of the threads of the thread pool. This argument cannot be null.
      config - the action called by this method to configure the ThreadPoolBuilder. This argument cannot be null.
      Returns:
      the executor with configuration set by the configuration action. The actual implementation of the returned executor is not defined, and must not be assumed to be a specific type of executor. This method never returns null.

    • setMaxThreadCount

      public void setMaxThreadCount(int maxThreadCount)
      Sets and overwrites previously set maximum allowed thread count. This is the maximum number of threads the created executor might spawn to run tasks concurrently. If you set this value to 1, then the returned executor is guaranteed to execute tasks in FIFO order.

      The default value for this property is 1.

      Parameters:
      maxThreadCount - the new maximum allowed thread count for the built executor. This value must be greater than or equal to 1.

    • setMaxQueueSize

      public void setMaxQueueSize(int maxQueueSize)
      Sets and overwrites previously set maximum queue size for the queue holding tasks to be executed once there is an available thread.

      The default value for this property is Integer.MAX_VALUE.

      Parameters:
      maxQueueSize - the new maximum allowed thread count for the built executor. This value must be greater than or equal to 1.

    • setIdleTimeout

      public void setIdleTimeout(TimeDuration idleTimeout)
      Sets and overwrites previously set timeout value for threads to expire after they had nothing to do for the given amount of time. When needed, new threads will be created in place of the expired threads up to maximum allowed thread count.

      The default value for this property is 5 seconds.

      Parameters:
      idleTimeout - the timeout value for idle threads to expire. This value can be null to set infinite timeout (i.e. threads will never expire unless the executor shuts down). The timeout may not be negative (but can be zero).

    • setThreadFactoryWithConfig

      public void setThreadFactoryWithConfig(Consumer<? super ThreadPoolBuilder.ThreadFactoryConfig> config)
      Sets and overwrites previously set factory to create new threads when the executor needs them. The passed configuration can be used to set whatever property is currently supported to be customized. If you need more customization, then consider setting your own implementation of ThreadFactory.

      The default value for this property is a thread factory creating non-daemon threads naming the threads based on the pool name.

      Parameters:
      config - the action configured the property for threads to be created. This configuration is called immediately by this method, and captured values of the thread factory will remain the same after. This argument cannot be null.

    • setThreadFactory

      public void setThreadFactory(ThreadFactory threadFactory)
      Sets and overwrites previously set factory to create new threads when the executor needs them. Note that you can create a completely custom name for the started threads, and the executor won't rename them. This also means, that in this case the pool name has little meaning.

      The default value for this property is a thread factory creating non-daemon threads naming the threads based on the pool name.

      Parameters:
      threadFactory - the factory to create new threads when the executor needs them. This argument cannot be null.

    • setManualShutdownRequired

      public void setManualShutdownRequired(boolean manualShutdownRequired)
      Sets and overwrites previously set value marking the executor to require explicit shutdown or not. The executor built is not required to make use of this property, but it might implement some error detection in case the executor was not shutdown explicitly. However, if you are creating an executor with 0 timeout, then shutting down the executor is not necessary to avoid having unnecessary threads, in which case you might never shut down the executor, in which case you must set this property to false.

      The default value for this property is true.

      Parameters:
      manualShutdownRequired - true if the built executor requires explicit shutdown, false otherwise

    • setFullQueueHandler

      public void setFullQueueHandler(FullQueueHandler fullQueueHandler)
      Sets and overwrites previously set handler defining a custom exception to be thrown in case the task queue of the executor is full. Setting this property will overwrite the previously set fallback executor.

      The default value for this property is a handler always instructing the executor to block and wait until it can execute the task.

      Parameters:
      fullQueueHandler - the new handler defining a custom exception to be thrown in case the task queue of the executor is full. This argument cannot be null.

    • setFullQueueHandlerToFallback

      public void setFullQueueHandlerToFallback(TaskExecutor fallbackExecutor)
      Sets and overwrites previously set handler falling back to the given executor when the task queue of the built executor is full. This feature relies on the fullQueueHandler, thus overwrites the value set for it.

      In case of falling back required, the same method of the fallback executor will be called as what was called for the built executor (with the exact same arguments).

      The default value for this property is a handler always instructing the executor to block and wait until it can execute the task. That is, no fallback will be made

      Parameters:
      fallbackExecutor - the executor to fall back to in case the task queue of the built executor is full. This argument cannot be null.

    • build

      public MonitorableTaskExecutorService build()
      Creates and returns a new executor using the previously set properties. This method captures the previously set properties, and subsequent modifications to this builder has no effect on the returned executor.

      Note: This method makes no guarantee on the type of the returned executor, and the actual implementation might change in future versions.

      Returns:
      a new executor using the previously set properties. This method never returns null.
